title: Glide bombs: Russia's secret to making cheap weapons
summary: Tactics (ep 1). Le Monde takes a look at how bomb optimization techniques are shaping Russia's strategy in Ukraine for the first installment of our 'Tactics' series on the transformation of modern warfare.

title: Israel's inhumane war in the Gaza Strip
summary: The all-out war waged against the Palestinian enclave has been marked by an unprecedented militarization of humanitarian action and a normalization of inhumane treatment inflicted on the civilian population, writes historian Jean-Pierre Filiu in his column.

title: Container ship carrying 'hazardous cargo' sinks off the Indian coast
summary: The ship, whose 24 crew members were rescued, was carrying 640 containers, 'including 13 with hazardous cargo and 12 containing calcium carbide,' when it sunk on Saturday, according to the Indian Ministry of Defense.

title: Shein assembles a lineup of former politicians to defend its interests
summary: In France, former interior minister Christophe Castaner and lawyer and former secretary of state Nicole Guedj are among the figures recruited to lobby for the Chinese behemoth, alongside Günther Oettinger, former European commissioner.

title: Iran summons French envoy after Foreign Minister Barrot's 'insulting' Cannes comments
summary: After dissident filmmaker Jafar Panahi won the Palme d'Or on Saturday, Jean-Noël Barrot called his victory 'a gesture of resistance against the Iranian regime's oppression.'

title: Lab mice sent to retire in a French elementary school classroom
summary: A pilot project by the Ethosph'R organization follows the adaptation of rodents while offering children education in ethology.

title: European and Arab nations gather in Spain to urge an end to Israel's offensive in Gaza
summary: The talks aimed to stop Israel's 'inhumane' and 'senseless' war in Gaza, Spanish Foreign Minister Jose Manuel Albares said. Humanitarian aid must enter Gaza 'massively, without conditions and without limits, and not controlled by Israel,' describing the territory as humanity's 'open wound.'

title: Emmanuel Macron arrives in Vietnam for the first leg of Southeast Asia tour
summary: During his six-day trip, which includes stops in Indonesia and Singapore, Macron will pitch France as a reliable alternative partner to the United States and China.

title: Roland Garros pays an emotional tribute to Rafael Nadal
summary: On May 25, the recently retired Nadal was serenaded by an adoring crowd during an 'unforgettable ceremony.' His long-time rivals - Roger Federer, Andy Murray and Novak Djokovic − joined him on the court: 'The toughest rivals probably in the history of our sport are able to be good colleagues, to respect each other. You don't need to hate the opponent to try to beat him with all your force.'

title: At least 13 killed in Ukraine after Russia's 'massive night attack'
summary: Russia launched a second straight night of major air strikes on Ukraine, including on the capital Kyiv, after pummeling the country with ballistic missiles and drones on Friday night. The two countries said they had completed the largest prisoner exchange on Sunday morning.

title: Are some tropical trees getting struck by lightning on purpose?
summary: Some remarkable trees in tropical forests seem to have developed strategies not only to survive lightning strikes but also to be struck more often than others, a recent American study reveals.

title: Opponents of the 2030 Winter Olympics in the Alps file two appeals demanding a public debate
summary: In the absence of any public consultation on the impact of hosting the 2030 Winter Olympics in the Alps, a citizens' collective has submitted complaints to both the Aarhus Convention Committee at the United Nations and France's administrative court system.

title: Six skiers die in Swiss mountain accidents
summary: The bodies of five skiers were found near the luxury Swiss resort Zermatt and another skier was killed in an avalanche on the Morgenhorn.

title: A spring without rain: Northern Europe faces exceptional early drought
summary: From the United Kingdom to Germany, from northern France to Sweden, large parts of Europe have experienced their driest spring in over a century. The situation is threatening agricultural yields and has led to water use restrictions.

title: Jafar Panahi wins Palme d'Or at politically charged Cannes Festival
summary: The Iranian filmmaker, known for his clandestine work, won the top prize for 'It Was Just an Accident,' a fierce attack against the Islamic Republic. The jury also gave two awards to  Brazilian director Kleber Mendonça Filho's 'The Secret Agent,' which explores Brazil's military dictatorship in the 1970s.

title: Seven unmissable festivals in France this summer
summary: Le Monde presents a tour of France's best summer events, from late June to mid-August.

title: After Cannes, Nice targeted by electrical sabotage
summary: An electrical transformer was set on fire in what appears to be an act of vandalism. Some 45,000 homes were temporarily without power in Nice and some neighboring towns. Power was restored by early Sunday morning.

title: The downsides of 'coliving,' the new shared housing industry
summary: Highly profitable, the business of room renting in renovated apartments thrives in France amid a housing crisis in large cities.

title: How French industries are adapting to US tariffs
summary: The trade war initiated by Donald Trump and his frequent policy shifts are plunging French companies into uncertainty. While some attempt to pass the increase in tariffs onto their customers, others are beginning to rethink their value chains and increase their production in the US.

title: Palestinian pediatrician in Gaza loses nine of her 10 children when her home is bombed
summary: Alaa al-Najjar was working at a hospital in the South of the Gaza Strip when her house was bombed. The only survivors − her husband and one of their 10 children − were wounded.

title: French documentary filmmaker Marcel Ophuls dead at 97
summary: The renowned filmmaker demolished one of France's most cherished myths with the release of 'The Sorrow and the Pity': that the French had unilaterally resisted the Germans during World War II. Ophuls always maintained, however, that it was not an attempt to prosecute the French. Who can say their nation would have behaved better in the same circumstances?'

title: Trump extends EU tariff deadline until July 9
summary: Trump had threatened on Friday to invoke the steep tariffs as soon as June 1, saying talks with the European Union over his previous levies were 'going nowhere.'

title: Sebastiao Salgado, photographer of the extraordinary, has died at 81
summary: The French-Brazilian, renowned worldwide for his sweeping black-and-white photographic narratives, was one of the last heirs of the humanist photography tradition.

title: The Syrian therapist who heals souls broken in Bashar al-Assad's prisons
summary: From her apartment in Damascus, Najwa Harba treats around 40 patients traumatized by their time in the jails of the former dictator. It is a difficult task in a country where discussing mental health remains fraught with challenges.

title: Savoring wine with the eyes: 'The color of a wine reveals its elegance, its youth, but also its maturity'
summary: Compared to scent and taste, sight is the sense people pay the least attention to during a wine tasting. Yet the appearance of wine, with its endless palette of shades, provides essential information.

title: The persistent threat of the Islamic State group in Syria
summary: With car bomb attacks in the Euphrates Valley, harassment of Kurdish forces and accusations of 'betrayal' against Ahmad al-Sharaa after his meeting with Donald Trump, jihadist cells are maintaining constant pressure on the new Syrian government.

title: Ukraine's air defense is struggling to keep up with intensifying Russian strikes
summary: Ukrainian territory has come under massive attacks in recent nights. Kyiv is beginning to run out of ammunition to counter these bombardments.

title: In Vietnam, Macron aims to seize on ongoing reforms to boost French investments
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron arrived in Vietnam on Sunday, the first leg of a Southeast Asian diplomatic tour.

title: Trump backtracks on new tariff threats against EU
summary: After a call with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, the US president postponed a possible increase in tariffs on products imported into the United States until July 9. He had threatened on Friday to impose a 50% tariff starting June 1.

title: French authorities blame sabotage for second power blackout on the Riviera
summary: They also called for heightened security after a fire at an electricity sub-station in Nice caused the second major power blackout in two days in southern France.

title: French Open: Richard Gasquet does not regret retiring: 'I gave everything to try to be the best'
summary: This French Open will be Richard Gasquet's last tournament, at 38. Here's why the best back-hander in French tennis never achieved the great success he seemed destined for.

title: Venezuela's Maduro wins landslide in election boycotted by opposition
summary: The United Socialist Party of Venezuela won 23 out of 24 state governor positions and scored 82.68% of the votes cast for lists of National Assembly members, the electoral council said.

title: Macron's entourage denies he was slapped by his wife on plane upon arriving in Vietnam
summary: Images shot by the Associated Press news agency as the president's plane arrived in Vietnam, in which Emmanuel Macron seemed to have been struck by his wife, Brigitte, were initially denied, and then downplayed by the Elysée.

title: 'Charlie Hebdo' files complaint over fake covers, blaming 'pro-Russian propaganda'
summary: The satirical magazine filed a complaint for counterfeiting with a Paris court after mock front pages disparaging Ukraine were shared on social media.

title: Former French PM faces backlash over proposal to ban headscarves for children
summary: Gabriel Attal, the head of President Macron's party, said he wanted to ban under-15s from wearing Muslim headscarves in public spaces. In response, there has been an outcry across the political spectrum, except on the far right.

title: Germany's Merz says Western allies no longer impose range limits on Ukrainian weapons
summary: The German chancellor said on Monday that the lifting of these restrictions will allow Ukraine to strike military positions in Russia and added that his government would strategically no longer detail what arms it is sending to Ukraine.

title: Russia takes over a second Orthodox church in Nice
summary: The courts have ruled in favor of Moscow, which claimed ownership of the French Riviera church that had been managed for more than a century by descendants of White Russian émigrés. Representatives of Russia have already sent a bailiff to the site.

title: French Open: Naomi Osaka eliminated by Paula Badosa in the first round
summary: The four-time Grand Slam champion was undone by 54 unforced errors and lost in the French Open's first round to 10th-seeded Paula Badosa 6-7 (1), 6-1, 6-4 on Monday.
